section-block.rac_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: How Big Is an Elephant?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Rossana Bossù
section-block.rac_book_summary: We know an elephant is big, but just how big IS an elephant? You need seven polar bears to make ONE elephant! This book challenges children to compare animals and think about relative sizes.

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce tools for measuring height: rulers, yard sticks, measuring tape. Demonstrate measuring objects using the appropriately-sized tool.
Play freeze dance. When you stop the music, have children freeze and say Big or Small. Children should make themselves seem big or small by stretching, crouching, etc.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read How Big is an Elephant? by Rossana Bossù.
You know that Lala loves all sorts of books. Did you know that she loves looking for measurements in informational books like this one?
While I read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is an example of a really big animal?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: As you read, point out height and length in context and ask children to make informal comparisons of animal sizes.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the words how big. What does it mean to ask how big something is? How big do you think an elephant is?
What animal is smaller than an elephant? We can learn how big an animal is by measuring it.
Elephants must be really big, because I think polar bears are big and we need seven polar bears to make one elephant!
Are polar bears big animals? What animals are smaller than a polar bear?
How many penguins make up one alligator? Let’s count the penguins we see on this page. (MB)
Which is bigger: an elephant or a whale?
Let’s discuss the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is an example of a really big animal?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question.
Write and read aloud short sentences comparing sizes of animals from the book as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What things do you measure in real life?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers understand that lengths and sizes of objects vary and can be compared. Children start by informally comparing the length, height, and size of objects and people around them. Help children develop this skill by using measurement vocabulary and asking children to measure using non-standard units of measurement.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Think Symbolically
section-block.rac_body-text: Thinking symbolically is tough for preschoolers, but we can help by explaining that symbols mean using one thing to stand for something else. When reading, we can use stuffed animals or puppets to represent characters. In math, numbers or blocks can represent how many. Point out symbolic thinking when you “catch” children doing it!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of How Big is an Elephant? by Rossana Bossù to practice thinking symbolically.
Clifford likes to find new ways of thinking symbolically. He thinks symbolically to think about how one thing can stand for, or take the place of, something else.

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Make means to be part of a whole. This means that one elephant is the same size as seven polar bears put together. Let’s imagine seven polar bears—that’s very big!
We are thinking symbolically when we say that you need four lions to make one polar bear. You can’t really combine four lions—we have to imagine what that would look like.
We can also think symbolically about numbers. If I show you the number 5, you know that means five of something, like five fingers. (MB)
Show how many lions make a polar bear using your fingers. (MB)
Point to the number card that shows how many alligators make a lion. (MB)
Is a lemur bigger or smaller than a penguin? How do you know?
It’s so hard to imagine how large a whale is. You have to add up all of those animals to make one whale! Whales are so big! (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Take children on a “size hunt” around the neighborhood or school building. Challenge children to find objects that are bigger or smaller than body parts. For example, one child might pick up a pebble smaller than a fingernail. Another child might find a leaf bigger than a hand. Ask follow up questions to help children understand the relative size of their objects. I see that the leaf is bigger than your hand. Is it bigger than a house? How do you know?
Transcribe children’s speech as they compare sizes of animals in the book or other animals.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Although it may be difficult for children to articulate their understanding of thinking symbolically, they already practice this skill multiple times daily. Even if they can’t explain it, children understand that numbers are symbolic representations of actual quantities, letters represent spoken language, and maps represent places. (Ryan/Redleafpress.org, 2008)

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice measuring using toys. Have children line up the toys by length. Use an informal measurement tool like blocks or cubes to measure the animals.
Recite and clap “Miss Mary Mack” with children. Point out how difficult it would be for an elephant to jump over a fence. Discuss how big the fence might be.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread How Big is an Elephant? by Rossana Bossù.
Lala loves reading books that teach us new things.
Measurement words tell us how big someone or something is. Think about this question as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we compare the sizes of animals?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversation with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A polar bear is a big animal! But it’s smaller than an elephant.
What is smaller than a polar bear? What other animals are smaller than a polar bear? You can tell if an animal is bigger or smaller by comparing heights, lengths, or weights to compare size.
A lion is bigger than an alligator. A bigger animal could be taller, longer, or heavier.
Which is smaller, an alligator or a penguin? How do you know? A smaller animal will be shorter or lighter than the other animal.
Another way to say this is that a penguin is bigger than a lemur. What other animals in this book are bigger than a lemur?
Which is smaller, a lemur or a flea? It takes over a million fleas to make one lemur. That’s a lot of fleas! (MB)
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
How can we compare the sizes of animals?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can measure which animal is bigger.
We can say which animal is heavier.
We can tell which animal is taller.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about ways to compare animals.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How could we compare a big animal and a small animal?
We can measure which animal is b____ (bigger).
I can compare which animal is bigger and smaller.
Can you think of other animals not in this book that are smaller than an elephant? Which ones?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: At this age, children start to understand that measurements can be used to compare two or more objects or people. Have children compare their heights with their friends. Line up by shortest to tallest and tallest to shortest, or compare how long some pencils are. Encourage children to arrange things in size order frequently.

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss the tools children have used to measure so far this week: How did we measure how big an elephant was? What did we use to measure our feet? Our height?
Gather classroom items that are very light and fairly heavy, such as a pencil and a hole puncher. Pass each object around the circle. Ask, Do you think this is heavy or light?

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Can Measure. It is an informational poster full of facts.
Lala can’t wait to look at this poster. She wants to learn how to measure!
How Big is an Elephant and I Can Measure each focus on different ways of measuring. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show How Big is an Elephant? cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The ruler in this picture is red. It has lines to show how many inches or centimeters an object is.
How can you tell that the crayon is short and the pencil is long?
The scale in this picture is made of wood. When one side of the scale is low, that means the object in it is heavy. What object in the picture is heavy?
When one side of the scale is high, that means the object is light. What in the picture is light?
This cup is empty. What could you do to make it full?
The red center of a thermometer is high when the temperature is hot, and is low when it is cold.
Do you think the red center would be high today, or low?

section.rac_body-text: Provide measuring tools as available: a ruler, a scale, measuring cups, and a thermometer. Encourage children to freely explore each tool. Suggest that children measure amounts of water from a sink, the temperature of different parts of the room, and the weight or length of different classroom objects.
Provide a writing prompt about what tools children might use to measure an elephant and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Some children may be more familiar with the Metric system than the US Standard system. Point out that the ruler in the picture shows both centimeters and inches, the measuring cups ounces and cups, and the thermometer Celsius and Fahrenheit. Encourage children to experiment with both systems of measurement as they explore the tools you provide.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children pretend to add fish to an aquarium. Use blocks as fish. Challenge children to add long, short, small, big, fat, and thin fish to their aquariums. Make them swim!
Choose a familiar animal song like “Old MacDonald Had a Farm”. Challenge children to act out how big or small the animal is as they dance and sing.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read How Big is an Elephant? one more time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Which is it?
We have learned about measurement and measurement tools. When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is something I can measure?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together, this time with volunteers acting out some of the measurements.
Let’s pretend to measure an elephant. What could we use to measure something so big? Let’s pretend to measure a giant elephant!
Let’s pretend we want to know how much a lion weighs. What tool could we use to weigh it? Let’s pretend to be a lion stepping on a scale.
Which is heavier: a penguin or an alligator? How do you know?
Which is lighter: a lemur or a penguin?
A flea is so teeny tiny! How could we measure a flea?
Let’s use what we know about these animals to put them in order from smallest to largest. Which animal is smallest? Which animal is bigger than the flea but smaller than the next bigger animal?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What is something I can measure?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can measure how tall or short something is.
I can measure how heavy or light something is.
I can measure animals, people, or toys.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about what size animal they would want to be and why. Invite children to share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can you find out how big an animal is?
What is something you really want to measure?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Collecting and Organizing Data
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Graphic representations are a powerful way for children to collect, organize, and understand data. Although the concept of data is abstract, children are able to interpret graphic representations of data and develop an understanding of the presented information. An added bonus of graphing is that it is fun for children!
